text: Fulfil her week, and we will give thee this also for the service which thou shalt serve with me yet seven other years.
text_kjv: Fulfil her week, and we will give thee this also for the service which thou shalt serve with me yet seven other years.
text_niv: Finish this daughter’s bridal week; then we will give you the younger one also, in return for another seven years of work.”
text_esv: Complete the week of this one, and we will give you the other also in return for serving me another seven years.”
text_nlt: “But wait until the bridal week is over; then we’ll give you Rachel, too — provided you promise to work another seven years for me.”
text_msg: Enjoy your week of honeymoon, and then we'll give you the other one also. But it will cost you another seven years of work."
text_nasb: 'Complete the week of this one, and we will give you the other also for the service which you shall serve with me for another seven years.'
context: Genesis 29:27 exists within the patriarchal society of ancient Mesopotamia. Marriage was primarily a social and economic arrangement, often involving bride prices or dowries, as seen here with Jacob serving Laban. Laban's manipulation of the marriage customs highlights the power dynamics. 'Fulfil her week' refers to completing the customary wedding festivities, likely a week-long celebration with feasting and communal gatherings. These celebrations were vital for solidifying the marital bond and integrating the bride into her new family. Levirate marriage, although not directly present, offers a glimpse into the importance of continuing a lineage. The concept of serving for a wife was established; Jacob's initial seven-year service was the bride price. The additional seven years cemented the deal for Rachel. Family honor and reputation were paramount, hence Laban's insistence on the older daughter marrying first, regardless of Jacob's preference. This deception showcases how personal desires were often subjugated to social expectations and familial obligations. The idea of a father controlling his daughters' marriage was common. The number seven held symbolic significance in ancient Near Eastern cultures, often associated with completeness or perfection. Jacob’s situation underscored how easily one could be exploited by someone in a position of power, especially within the complex web of kinship and social custom. Contracts, while possibly verbal in this context, were taken seriously, and breaking them would carry significant consequences.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 29:27 reveals a complex interplay of divine sovereignty and human agency. While Laban's actions are deceitful and driven by self-interest, God uses these circumstances to further His purposes. Jacob, though a victim of deception, is ultimately held accountable for his own choices – including deceiving his father, Isaac. The verse highlights the theme of delayed gratification and the consequences of sin. Jacob's eagerness to marry Rachel blinds him to Laban's manipulative nature, resulting in fourteen years of labor. This mirrors the concept of sin having immediate allure but long-term consequences. God does not necessarily prevent hardship but often works through it. Jacob's story serves as a reminder that even in difficult circumstances, God's plan unfolds. The unfairness of Laban's actions underscores the reality of injustice in the world. Despite this, the narrative suggests that God's promises to Jacob (land, descendants, blessing) will ultimately be fulfilled, even through difficult circumstances. The verse also points to the importance of covenant faithfulness. Though Laban is not a follower of God, he recognizes the importance of fulfilling his agreement, albeit for selfish reasons. This contrasts with Jacob's own past actions of deception, prompting reflection on integrity and honesty. The extended period of servitude can be interpreted as a form of purification or refinement for Jacob, preparing him for his future role as the father of the twelve tribes of Israel.
application: Genesis 29:27 speaks powerfully to modern challenges of commitment, integrity, and patience. It reminds us to be wary of manipulative individuals who prioritize personal gain over ethical behavior. In personal relationships, particularly marriage, it underscores the importance of honesty and commitment. 'Fulfil her week' can be interpreted as honoring our commitments, even when they become difficult or less desirable. We should avoid shortcuts or deception in our pursuit of goals, remembering that integrity is more valuable than immediate gratification. The verse speaks to the problem of power imbalances in relationships and business. We should be mindful of the vulnerability of others and avoid exploiting them for personal gain. In career and financial matters, it warns against making hasty decisions driven by immediate desires. The 'seven other years' represent the long-term consequences of short-sighted choices. It encourages us to consider the long-term implications of our actions and to seek wise counsel before making major commitments. Furthermore, Jacob’s experience teaches us resilience in the face of adversity. Even when we are wronged, we can learn and grow from our experiences. The story also highlights the importance of trusting in God’s plan, even when we don't understand it. Like Jacob, we may face unexpected challenges, but we can trust that God will ultimately work all things together for good. It prompts self-reflection on our own behavior, asking us whether we are acting with integrity in our relationships and commitments. Are we willing to serve and sacrifice for the long-term benefit of others, or are we primarily focused on our own immediate needs and desires?
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for revealing your character through scripture. Help us to learn from Jacob's story, both his mistakes and his eventual triumph. Grant us discernment to recognize manipulation and to stand firm in our commitment to integrity. Give us patience to endure hardship and faith to trust in your plan, even when we don't understand it. Soften our hearts to be aware of our own selfishness, and move us towards service and sacrifice. Help us to honor our commitments and to be people of our word. Give us the wisdom to see the long-term consequences of our choices. Guide us towards fulfilling Your purposes, and teach us to find joy in serving others. In Jesus’ name, Amen.

faqs.answer: It refers to the customary week-long wedding celebration. This included feasting, festivities, and communal acknowledgement of the marriage, essential for integrating the bride into her new family and solidifying the union within the community.
faqs.question: Q1 What does 'fulfil her week' specifically refer to?

faqs.answer: Laban cited local custom, claiming it was unacceptable to marry the younger daughter before the older. This was likely a convenient excuse to deceive Jacob and secure the benefits of Jacob's continued labor.
faqs.question: Q2 Why did Laban insist on Leah marrying Jacob first?

faqs.answer: This verse reinforces the recurring theme of deception. Jacob, a deceiver himself, becomes the victim of Laban's deception. It illustrates the cyclical nature of sin and its consequences in human relationships.
faqs.question: Q3 How does this verse relate to the theme of deception in Genesis?

faqs.answer: While God doesn't directly intervene in Laban's deception, it shows He allows free will and uses difficult situations to shape individuals. God can work through flawed characters to fulfill His promises.
faqs.question: Q4 What can we learn about God's character from this passage?

faqs.answer: Yes, the number seven often represents completeness or perfection in ancient Near Eastern cultures and in the Bible. Jacob serving seven years twice signifies the full price he must pay for the women he wants.
